item.title: A Skating Rink Was Built Around a Luciano Pavarotti Statue. People Aren’t Thrilled.
item.description: “Nessun Dorma?” More like “Ice, Ice Baby,” as a statue in Italy is overshadowed.

item.title: Aid Workers Stand Trial for Helping to Smuggle People Into Greece
item.description: The activists provided support to people who sought sanctuary in Greece during Europe’s migration crisis.

item.title: Groups Express Anixety as Trump Threatens to Derail U.S.-Mexico-Canada Trade Pact
item.description: Hearings that began Wednesday in Washington reflected anxiety over the future of the U.S.-Mexico-Canada trade pact and whether the president could end up scrapping it.

item.title: Yasser Abu Shabab, Militant Leader Backed by Israel, Is Killed in Gaza, Official Says
item.description: Yasser Abu Shabab, a Bedouin man in his 30s, was at the center of an Israeli project in Gaza to build up anti-Hamas militias.

item.title: Putin Must Have Authorized Novichok Poisoning in Salisbury, UK Inquiry Finds
item.description: The death of a British woman from Novichok was the result of a botched assassination attempt on a former Russian spy, an official report said on Thursday.

item.title: The Diplomat Who Was Accused of Sexual Abuse but Kept His Job
item.description: President William Ruto faces pressure after a Times investigation showed that his government downplayed or ignored the mistreatment of women working in Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Ruined Rice Fields and Broken Rail Lines: Sri Lanka Counts Cost of Cyclone
item.description: Officials estimate the damage runs into billions of dollars, a headache for the island nation just recovering from an economic crash.

item.title: What to Know About Putin’s Visit to India as Oil Trade Dries Up
item.description: The Trump administration, which crippled Russia’s oil sales to India with sanctions, will be watching Mr. Putin’s talks with Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

item.title: His Group Made World-Class Measurements of Atomic Elements
item.description: Yuri Ralchenko led one of the oldest teams at the National Institute for Standards and Technology. The fate of some experiments hangs in the air.

item.title: Deadly Attacks in Gaza Test Cease-Fire as Body of Another Captive Is Returned
item.description: Israel launched a military strike after it said Hamas militants attacked its soldiers, the latest clashes in the two months since a truce was signed.

item.title: Cambodia Shuts Down Group That Laundered Billions in Scam Profits
item.description: A New York Times investigation in March found that Huione’s group of companies were at the heart of a global money laundering network for fraudsters, scammers and hackers.

item.title: How Israel’s Settlement Surge in the West Bank Is Displacing Palestinians
item.description: The Israeli government authorized 22 settlements in May, the largest expansion in decades, and Palestinian families are now being forced from their homes.

item.title: Trump to Host Congo and Rwanda Leaders for Peace Talks in Persistent Conflict
item.description: The president will meet with the leaders of Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo to advance a deal meant to end a long war in eastern Congo.

item.title: Spain Sees Itself as a Beacon for Immigrants. So Do Many Latin Americans.
item.description: The government presents its migrant policy as a welcoming alternative to U.S. crackdowns. But activists say those arriving on boats from Africa are excluded from that embrace.

item.title: Snail Theft Hits France Before Holiday Rush
item.description: Shop owners say the thieves who took 990 pounds of snails must have been escargot cognoscenti.

item.title: Macron Urges Xi to Help End War in Ukraine
item.description: As President Emmanuel Macron of France visited China, its leader, Xi Jinping, said his country would play a constructive role in ending the fighting.

item.title: Hamas Returns Body of Last Thai Hostage in Gaza
item.description: The militant group took more than 250 hostages from Israel on Oct. 7, 2023, including 31 from Thailand. The remains of all but one other hostage, an Israeli, have been recovered.

item.title: Stakes High, Europe Races to Save Its Financing Plan for Ukraine
item.description: The European Union has a proposal for how to turn Russian frozen assets into a giant loan for Ukraine. If it fails, it could further weaken Europe’s global image.

item.title: Taiwan’s Opposition Leader, Once for Independence, Turns Toward China
item.description: She says Taiwan must embrace its Chinese heritage to avoid war. Her critics say she wants to steer the island into Beijing’s orbit.

item.title: China, Japan and a New Narrative About World War II
item.description: Arguments about history are proliferating as the postwar order led by the United States crumbles.

item.title: Fabergé Winter Egg Sells for $30 Million, an Auction Record
item.description: Fabergé is believed to have produced 50 of the ornate eggs for Russia’s czars. The Winter Egg, sold on Tuesday, is considered one of the jewelry house’s greatest creations.

item.title: Storm Floodwaters in Indonesia Turned Logs Into Floating Projectiles
item.description: Many logs became forces of destruction in Indonesia last week, in a sign that deforestation compounded the devastation wrought by a cyclone.

item.title: Trump Faces Choices on Russia-Ukraine Talks as Peace Deal Deadline Passes
item.description: The president wanted Moscow and Kyiv to come to terms by Thanksgiving. Negotiations are now stalled, leaving the White House to decide if an agreement is possible anytime soon.

item.title: What to Know About Trump’s Threat of Military Action in Venezuela
item.description: The president has warned that the United States could soon expand its attacks from boats near the coast to targets inside Venezuela, but he has also spoken by phone to its leader.

item.title: In Yemen, Separatist Forces Backed by UAE March Into Oil-Rich Region
item.description: The separatists were battling to secure the region’s oil fields, residents and the group’s officials said. Their swift advance could be a turning point in Yemen’s decade-long civil war.

item.title: Tunisia Arrests Opposition Figure in Widening Crackdown
item.description: The sentencing of Ayachi Hammami, a prominent human rights lawyer, was the latest sign of Tunisia’s backsliding into authoritarianism, say rights groups.

item.title: South Korea Says the U.S. Agreed to Help It Secure Fuel for Reactors
item.description: President Lee Jae Myung reaffirmed wanting to build nuclear-powered submarines at home, despite President Trump’s suggestion that they be built in the United States.

item.title: Ludwig Minelli, Founder of Swiss Assisted-Suicide Group, Dies at 92
item.description: Dignitas has helped more than 3,000 people take their own lives, an act that Mr. Minelli maintained was a fundamental exercise of free will.

item.title: Yegor Ligachev, Gorbachev’s No. 2 Who Turned Foe, Is Dead at 100
item.description: As the Kremlin’s hard-line Communist ideologist, he initially embraced his boss’s modernizing reforms before turning against them as threats to the Soviet order.

item.title: On Trump’s Insults, Somalia’s Prime Minister Says ‘It’s Better Not to Respond’
item.description: President Trump referred to Somali immigrants as “garbage” during a White House meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: Macy’s Raises Sales Forecast Again as Shoppers Prove Resilient
item.description: Macy’s raised its sales forecast for the year after strong results at its upscale chain, highlighting how higher-income consumers continue to spend relatively freely.

item.title: With Tensions Rising, Israel and Lebanon Expand Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: Diplomats from both countries joined a military-led committee overseeing a year-old truce as fears mounted of a renewed Israeli offensive against Hezbollah.

item.title: Two U.K. Women’s Groups Ban Transgender Girls and Women
item.description: The Girlguiding organization and the Women’s Institute both said a court ruling from earlier this year had forced their hands.

item.title: Weak Spots Are Few for Russia in Ukraine Peace Talks
item.description: Economic and military pressures could force Russia’s hand. Its economy is strained but not enough to do that, analysts say. And President Vladimir V. Putin says Russia is winning the war.

item.title: Israel Says a Gaza Border Will Reopen, but Only for Palestinians to Leave
item.description: Israel had agreed to open the Rafah crossing as part of the October cease-fire deal with Hamas but kept it closed. Egypt denied that the border would reopen soon.

item.title: After Deadly Attacks, Australia Debates: Do Shark Nets Work?
item.description: Critics say the nets harm marine life and aren’t the best way to keep swimmers safe. Recent shark attacks have complicated a plan to remove some of them.

item.title: A Devastating Fire Has Fueled a National Security Crackdown in Hong Kong
item.description: The authorities quickly arrested critics demanding accountability, signaling an expansive use of the security law to silence dissent over nonpolitical tragedies.

item.title: Canada Turns to the World’s Polar Bear Capital to Defend its Arctic
item.description: The tiny town of Churchill has two of Canada’s largest pieces of Arctic infrastructure, but years of neglect have left them in poor shape amid growing superpower rivalry in the region.

item.title: Europe Wants to Get the Word Out: Russia Is to Blame for Sabotage
item.description: Officials are accusing Russia of smaller-scale assaults. President Vladimir V. Putin sought to turn the tables, saying that if Europe were to start a war, Russia is ready.

item.title: Thousands Greet Pope Leo as He Prays Near Site of Beirut Port Blast
item.description: A waterfront Mass in the Lebanese capital capped the pope’s three-day visit to the Middle Eastern nation with the largest proportion of Christians.

item.title: Visiting Turkey and Lebanon, Pope Leo Echoed Francis’s Message, Not His Style
item.description: Traveling through the Mideast, Leo XIV channeled many of his predecessor’s messages. Leo’s deliberate manner differed from Francis.

item.title: Inside the Ultra-Orthodox Fight Against Israel’s Draft
item.description: For the first time in decades, ultra-Orthodox Jews in Israel are being called to serve in the country’s military. The community is furious, with protesters and military-age men openly defying the draft.

item.title: Environmentally Friendly Coffee
item.description: Here’s what to know about your daily brew and the environment.

item.title: 120,000 Home Cameras Were Hacked for Sexual Videos, South Korean Police Say
item.description: The authorities arrested four people this week in the latest turn in the country’s effort to stop exploitative recordings.

item.title: Our Top Editor Answers Questions
item.description: Joe Kahn, The New York Times’s executive editor, was asked about how we cover the news and make judgment calls in our reporting and editing.

item.title: The Philippines Spent Big on Flood Control, but the Water Keeps Rising
item.description: Many Filipinos say floods are worse than ever — and now, the government has admitted that vast sums were embezzled from a program meant to fight the problem.

item.title: In Photos and Video: Devastating Floods Swamp Parts of Asia
item.description: Images of the destruction caused by storms that have torn through South and Southeast Asia.

item.title: U.N. Security Council to Visit Syria and Lebanon at ‘Crucial’ Time for the Countries
item.description: The trip comes days before the anniversary of the fall of Bashar al-Assad, and as Lebanon is navigating the cease-fire between Hezbollah and Israel.

item.title: Putin and Witkoff Meet in Russia as U.S. Pushes Ukraine Deal
item.description: The two sides did not reach any specific compromises, an aide to President Vladimir V. Putin said, as the United States pushes a plan to end the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Reckoning With a New Era of Deadly Floods
item.description: The floods and landslides that have killed more than 1,350 people in recent weeks are a grim reminder of the risks of a warming planet.

item.title: Maduro Faces His Ultimate Fight as Trump Threatens Military Action in Venezuela
item.description: President Trump’s threat of military action has confronted President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela with the gravest challenge of his crisis-ridden reign.

item.title: Sharks and Rays Gain Sweeping Protections from Wildlife Trade
item.description: A global treaty has extended trade protections to more than 70 shark and ray species whose numbers are in sharp decline.

item.title: Right to Jury Trial in England and Wales to Be Restricted in Some Cases
item.description: The British justice secretary, David Lammy, announced the contentious move on Tuesday as part of an attempt to tackle a yearslong backlog in the courts.

item.title: Marcos vs. Marcos: The New Front in Philippine Politics
item.description: President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. is under fire for an enormous graft scandal that is unfolding under his watch. One prominent voice is his sister Senator Imee Marcos.

item.title: China, Evoking World War II, Urges Europe to Take Its Side Against Japan
item.description: A diplomatic row with Japan over Taiwan has China turning to Britain and France for support, appealing to their shared history as wartime allies.

item.title: Trump Alleges Fraud, Without Evidence, in Honduras Election
item.description: Honduras was on edge after tallies showed two candidates separated by about 500 votes. Then President Trump claimed that officials were rigging results.
